However, the structure of hydrate under high pressure and temperature conditions has not been well studied. In this work, we report the structure of hydrate at high pressure and temperature.

The foundations of quantum theory are one of the most important and most controversial areas of contemporary mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is based on the idea that the category of Hilbert spaces and linear operators is equivalent to the category of sets and functions whose functions are continuous with respect to a certain distance. This result resolves a long-standing question in the foundations of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which includes the distinctive polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we provide the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus has a complex life cycle that involves the host immune system. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key factors in the induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity. We also show that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, which is involved in the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new strategies to combat the pandemic. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the world’s major maize-exporting countries. The increase in variability will also increase the probability of global maize production losses greater than 10% in any given year. These results highlight the importance of breeding for heat tolerance, which will be critical to the sustainability of global maize production.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is critical to understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in natural communities. However, the extent to which different species partition food resources at the level of individual species is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in body size and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition at the species level. This approach will be critical for understanding the role of niche partitioning in the ecology and evolution of large herbivores.

We provide evidence on the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on small businesses. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is a key determinant of the expected duration of business closures. Many small businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of the human impact on the environment. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is thought to have formed from the aggregation of dust particles in the interstellar medium. However, the age of the solar system is still a matter of debate. In this study, we determined the ages of silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The ages range from 3.9 Ma to ∼3 Ga, which is much older than the age of the solar system.

We provide a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of the global fishing fleet, which has doubled in size since 1950. We show that the expansion of the motorized fleet has been driven by the powered-artisanal sector, which has grown from 10% to 68% of the global fleet. The powered-artisanal fleet has been responsible for the majority of the increase in engine power, which has increased by a factor of 5.8 since 1950. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, but there are signs of stabilization and more effective management in recent years.

The ability to produce offspring is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also one of the most difficult to increase. We show that the increase in reproductive output is due to the increase in the mother’s metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is responsible for the C-terminal truncation of α-syn in MSA. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA and other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells, and each cell is responsible for a specific function. This paper describes the design of the communication network between the cells of the endothelium. The network is composed of clusters of cells that are connected to each other by short paths. The network is also highly synchronizable, which allows for rapid and robust communication between the cells. The design of the network is effective for both local and global communication and is therefore an efficient way to control the functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated a huge amount of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic, for public health response, and for research. We describe the data sources and signals in the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to many of these data at a fine geographic resolution. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are updated daily, and all of the data are available in a common format through the API. This provides a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners, and we hope that it will be useful for many applications.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in human health and disease. In recent years, the role of anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome has been investigated, and it has been suggested that these fungi may play a role in the regulation of the microbiome. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products, which could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is involved in the establishment of social hierarchies, in the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic link between anxiety and social behavior, which may be of interest to the field of social neuroscience. (PsycINFO Database Record

This paper presents a general framework for the design of multifunctional structures with programmable mechanical responses. The framework is based on the synthesis of composite structures composed of multiple materials, which are optimally designed to produce specific responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are then fabricated into devices with programmable responses. The proposed framework can be extended to design structures with programmable responses under other types of deformations, such as shape changes and motion. The proposed framework can be applied to design a wide range of multifunctional devices, such as soft robots, soft actuators, and soft sensors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In this study, we demonstrate that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is expressed in the erythroid lineage, is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans. Our results suggest that the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans is regulated by a mechanism that is similar to that in mice.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, promotes lipogenesis through SREBP1/SCD1-mediated regulation of fatty acid metabolism. We propose that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. This strategy may be particularly effective in cancer cells with hyperactive PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling, such as those with mutations in the PI3K or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN). Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cardiovascular disease, and the use of antihypertensive drugs is widespread. However, the mechanisms of action of these drugs are not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of antihypertensive drugs, which are used in millions of patients worldwide, act on the Ca2+ signaling machinery in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of these drugs and for the development of new drugs.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP has not yet been successful in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem area has been stable, but has declined in two ecoregions. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this study, we present a rational design approach for the development of new acylide antibiotics. The design strategy is based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. We tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy is expected to be a useful tool for the rational development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations and is able to capture features at different scales. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures, and is easier to train and apply in practice. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results for several segmentation problems.

The evolution of the African Rift System is a classic example of the impact of climate change on the formation of mountain ranges and the subsequent impact of these mountains on the evolution of the landscape. This study shows that the evolution of the African Rift System is also a classic example of the impact of climate change on the evolution of a lake system.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime phase-detains the circadian clock, suppresses melatonin, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These effects are likely to have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

The YDB is one of the most important events in the history of the Earth. It marks the end of the last ice age and the beginning of the Holocene. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Os isotopic composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with a terrestrial origin. The Os in the magnetic grains/microspherules is likely derived from the Earth.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We provide the most comprehensive dataset to date on the evolution of beetles, including the first estimates of beetle diversification rates. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that the size of the population in which people learn about artifacts affects the rate at which those artifacts improve. We also show that the rate of improvement is not enhanced by the size of the population, but rather is reduced.

Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to late-onset Alzheimer’s disease is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for Alzheimer’s disease, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold increased risk. These data put APOE central to Alzheimer’s disease pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify Alzheimer’s disease risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the Earth and the dynamics of the core. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. This paper provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core formation.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common features of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in language processing, which have no direct connection to the brain, are able to explain nearly all of the predictive brain activity and behavioral performance in the language domain. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in language comprehension, and suggest that the brain may use similar mechanisms to understand language.

Deep learning has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been difficult to use in scientific computing. We show that this difficulty is due to the instability of deep learning, which is a consequence of the curse of dimensionality. We introduce a new class of neural networks that are stable, and we prove that these networks can be computed efficiently. This opens the door for deep learning to be used in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of public debate. In this context, the role of psychology in the pandemic is a matter of intense interest. In this paper, we discuss the role of psychology in the COVID-19 pandemic, and in particular the role of a classic psychological experiment.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. In this paper, we report the genome sequence of a new leprosy bacterium, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. This is the first report of a leprosy bacterium from Mexico, and the phylogeographic survey suggests that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of leprosy and the mechanisms that have led to the loss of functions required for survival in the human host. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the laws of thermodynamics, respectively. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is captured by the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement evolution, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we provide a general framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the most effective way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is a live attenuated virus vaccine that is easy to manufacture, has a long shelf life, and is highly protective.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the history of humanity. In this paper, we present a mathematical model for the spread of plague by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe. It also provides a framework for understanding the history of other diseases spread by ectoparasites.

The evolution of brain size is one of the most studied topics in biology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the ability to process information, is still poorly understood. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is not only different from the evolution of brain size but also has a different scaling with body size.

This paper is about a protein that is found in the mitochondria of all cells. It is a molecular chaperone, which means that it helps other proteins fold correctly. It is also a member of a family of proteins that are involved in the development of cancer. This paper shows that the function of this protein is important for the growth of cancer cells.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell motility, cell division, and cell death. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is not well understood. Here, we show that the action of ADF/cofilin is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the actin filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in a variety of biological processes. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other mechanochemical enzymes.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and for the design of interventions to reduce the risk of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also affected by the geography of the island, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. These results provide a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar and help to understand the diversity of the Malagasy population. This article is protected by copyright. We show that the content of people’s Facebook News Feeds influences their emotions. We find that people who see more positive content in their News Feed become more positive themselves, and that people who see more negative content become more negative. These results suggest that people are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook, and that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook, and that in-person interaction is not necessary for emotional contagion.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation, and the presence of chemical modifications in these sequences can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can alter the rate of protein synthesis, and that this effect can be observed in both the bacterial and human cell systems. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis and for the development of new strategies for controlling protein expression. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are robust to the inclusion of a range of potential confounders, and they are also evident in a longitudinal analysis, indicating that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key factor in promoting positive outcomes across the life course.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important topics in biology. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

This study is a major advance in our understanding of the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of pili and their role in bacterial sensing and signaling.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide problem. It shows that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. The results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

This study provides a unique perspective on the role of wildlife in the COVID-19 pandemic. It is the first study to document the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer, and the first to show that deer can transmit the virus. The findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and for the development of a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major problem that is being ignored by the hydropower industry. This paper examines the problems of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and proposes solutions. We show that the industry is ignoring the problems of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and that the problems are being ignored by the industry because the industry is not being held accountable for the problems.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a global public health crisis. The disease is thought to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins, which are toxic to neurons. However, we show here that the intraneuronal burden of Aβ is also toxic, and that it is the Aβ-burdened neuron that initiates the inflammatory response in AD. This finding has implications for the development of new therapies, since it suggests that targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a more effective approach than targeting the Aβ plaques.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most complex, as it is the result of a long process of acclimatization of a wild species. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. This study shows that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although there are several therapeutic strategies for the treatment of sepsis, there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. Our results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature, where a system, in the course of time, adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state, in which the system adjusts its dynamics to maintain a critical state, in which the rate of change of the system is such that the system is always close to the critical point. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, diamond is a brittle material, and its mechanical properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be fully opened, without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The female reproductive tract is a critical site of sperm maturation and fertilization. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to sperm function is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the maintenance of sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to the glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) receptor on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow. We show that the A1 domain in VWF can be switched to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The mechanism is also relevant to the function of VWF in hemostasis. This work provides a mechanism for the action of a protein in blood, and may lead to the development of new therapies.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential for human health. However, the role of viruses in human health is less clear. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to identify associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to elucidate the role of viruses in human health, and provide a resource for future studies.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the instrument to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of great interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for the survival of life on the planet. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is also important for the evolution of the Earth. This study provides a new perspective on the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Ion channels are the main ion transporters in the cell membrane. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into three types: voltage-gated, ligand-gated, and calcium-gated. The K+ channel is the most important type of ion channel. It is the main ion transporter in the heart, kidney, and other excitable tissues. It is also the main target of drugs.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 500,000 deaths per year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell, the host cell. Here, we show that one of the key mechanisms is the binding of the parasite to the surface of the host cell, which alters the biophysical properties of the cell. This change in the cell’s surface properties, in turn, reduces the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate entry. This work also provides a platform for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This work provides a new approach to tailoring the properties of diamond. It also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease, and seasonal outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in host defense against influenza infection. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza. The brain is thought to build a hierarchical representation of the structure of a sentence, from the beginning to the end of the sentence. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain actually does this. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each word in a sentence, but suddenly increases when a word is merged into a phrase. This suggests that the brain uses a merge operation to build phrases from words. Our results provide initial evidence for the existence of a neural merge operation, and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin. This is an example of a subtle feature that may be used in the regulation of other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.
This paper is about the brain circuits that promote overeating. It is a very important contribution to the field of obesity, and it is written in a way that is accessible to the general public.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are essential for the growth of both organisms, and the establishment of these associations is critical for the health of the plant. In this work, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of symbiosis. This synthetic system may be used to develop a new generation of nitrogen-fixing crops that are more sustainable and efficient. (Show more)

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. The results suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sounds of its prey and predators, and even the sounds of its own kind, by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic signals than the spider itself. The spider can detect the direction and location of the source of the sound, and can even localize the sound in three dimensions. The spider can also adjust the size of its web to the sound intensity, and can regenerate the web to keep it in good condition. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing hearing in animals.

We provide a comprehensive analysis of the climate and health impacts of fossil fuel use, and of the benefits of a phaseout. We show that fossil fuel use is responsible for 65% of the excess mortality and 70% of the aerosol cooling. We also show that aerosols are responsible for 10–70% of the rainfall increase over India and 10–30% over China, and for 10–40% over Central America, West Africa, and the Sahel. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has resulted in millions of deaths. The development of vaccines is critical to controlling the pandemic. This study reports the design, synthesis, and characterization of a recombinant protein vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, which is critical for global access. The vaccine candidate is based on a sequence variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells. The vaccine candidate exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, which is the receptor for SARS-CoV-2, and can be presented on a virus-like particle, which is a well-established vaccine platform. The vaccine candidate can be produced at large scale, which is critical for global access. The results provide a promising vaccine candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. We report on the discovery of a new class of ligands for the ALK receptor, which are secreted proteins that are expressed in the nervous system.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis is one of the most notorious. However, the early history of plague is poorly understood, and the timing and geographic spread of its evolution are still debated. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during its formative years. Our results suggest that the pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps before its emergence, and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. These data provide insights into the early history of plague and its adaptation to its vector, the flea. This work also highlights the importance of ancient DNA in understanding the origins of pathogens. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, a candidate who was widely perceived as a threat to women’s and men’s rights. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of native grasslands to cropland has released a large amount of carbon to the atmosphere. This study shows that the management of agricultural lands can mitigate this release. The results of this study have implications for the management of agricultural lands worldwide.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results of this framework and to prioritize research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is the reward that most flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of the color are not well understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and demonstrate that the same three enzymatic activities are necessary for the production of the color in two distantly related plants visited by different pollinators. Our findings suggest that the production of a red color is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that underlie the production of the color of nectar and the evolution of this trait in plants.

We provide a snapshot of the genetic ancestry of a group of women who lived in southern Germany at the end of the Roman Empire. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was very heterogeneous, and that they had a very high degree of admixture with populations from different parts of the world. In addition, we provide evidence that some of the women had artificial skull deformations, which may have been associated with the visible characteristics of their genetic ancestry. Finally, we provide evidence that some of the women had a genetic ancestry that was already at modern-like frequencies in Europe at the end of the Roman Empire.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. In this study, we found that HKU4, but not HKU5, shares a common receptor with MERS-CoV, but not with bat cells, and that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. These results suggest that bats are a potential reservoir of MERS-CoV, and that the use of human cells for cross-species transmission is a key adaptation for MERS-CoV to cause severe disease in humans. These findings are important for understanding the origins of MERS-CoV and for preventing future outbreaks. (Show more)

This study is a proof of concept for the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in the identification of pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. The study also highlights the importance of mNGS in the early detection of emerging pathogens, such as chikungunya virus, and the identification of zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi. The study also demonstrates the feasibility of mNGS in the identification of pathogens in a resource-scarce setting.

This paper is a major contribution to our understanding of the structure and function of the human replisome. It provides a unique insight into the dynamics of the human replisome and the factors that control the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this study, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA-based cell.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the population density of the neighborhood, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

COVID-19 is a new type of pneumonia, which is caused by a novel coronavirus. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the early stage, and there is no specific treatment. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, can improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results of this study provide a new idea for the treatment of COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but at high concentrations it is toxic. The ability of fungi to control copper availability is important for their health and for the health of the environment. Here we describe the existence of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. This is an example of a previously unknown role for a fungal natural product in the control of copper availability and in the control of microbial interactions.

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, is a unique feature of the geology of Gale crater, Mars. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at the base of a crater wall/rim/central peak suggests that the peak was formed by a volcanic event. The formation of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is also consistent with the presence of a large body of water in the vicinity of the peak.

Frost events are a major threat to plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is associated with the evolutionary history of the species that are most affected by them. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of colitis by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells may be a target for therapeutic intervention in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells that control muscle movement. The disease is difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. Here, we report a method to convert human fibroblasts into induced astrocytes, which are the cells that protect motor neurons from degeneration. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to find effective treatments for ALS. This approach will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the microbiota of its vector. This study also provides a model for understanding the role of the microbiota in pathogen colonization of vector insects.
This paper is about the evolution of the avian body plan, and in particular the origin of the modern avian tail. It is about the origin of the modern bird body plan.

We show that the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature is a feedback that can amplify the response to greenhouse gases. This feedback is not included in most climate models, and its magnitude is not well constrained.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the color of an animal can be used to assess its health, identity, and even its species. In this study, we describe a new type of color-changing protein, which is responsible for the green color of some frogs.

This study provides a mechanism for the role of hypoxia in the maintenance of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the metastatic potential of the tumor. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a method that can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of the parchment, as well as the number of species used in the production of the parchment.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a critical control on the timing of the onset of global environmental perturbation, the timing of the onset of mass extinction, and the timing of the recovery of the biota. The age model presented here provides a precise age for the onset of the extinction and a precise age for the recovery of the biota.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor family, which is involved in a variety of biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the role of RORα in the intestine and may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 is a promising target for vaccine development. However, the majority of currently circulating viruses have a single amino acid substitution, D614G, which may alter the structure and function of the spike protein. Here, we show that the D614G substitution leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G substitution and may inform the design of vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in the context of the search for new materials. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of interest to the scientific community working in the fields of chemistry, physics, and materials science.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity over the last century. This has led to a reduction in fire activity, which has the potential to reduce global warming. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain, and it is likely to be small relative to other drivers of climate change. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in shaping the future fire regime and the need to consider the role of fire in climate mitigation strategies.

This paper is about the symbiosis between a squid and its luminescent bacteria. The bacteria are very important for the squid, because they produce light, which is used for communication and for finding mates. The squid provides the bacteria with a special nutrient, which the bacteria use to produce light. The paper is about the timing of the delivery of this nutrient.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it is applicable to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which began in the 14th century, was the consequence of the introduction of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, into Europe. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. Our analysis shows that the introduction of plague into Europe was the result of repeated introductions of the bacterium, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y.

We provide evidence that a densovirus is responsible for the asteroid mass mortality on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with an asteroid disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common hematological malignancies, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of targets for treatment is therefore of great importance. In this study, we identified IL1RAP as a target for treatment of AML. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can also suppress the proliferation of AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be of great importance for the treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also revealed by the analysis of the genomic diversity. We find that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased manner, with a recent demographic growth. Finally, we show that the genomic diversity is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a heterogeneous manner. These results provide a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. View Full-Text

Bacteria are able to regulate gene expression in response to environmental changes. One of the most common types of regulatory RNA is the small RNA, which is found in a variety of organisms. In this study, we describe a small RNA that encodes a protein in Escherichia coli. The protein is membrane associated and interacts with a membrane enzyme. The RNA is also able to regulate the expression of two other genes. This is the first example of a small RNA that encodes a protein and is able to regulate the expression of multiple genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey of the US Department of Agriculture can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is robust to changes in the number of surveyors, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other agricultural commodities such as livestock, fisheries, and forestry.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to the context of the stimulus and can be used to bind information over time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and provide a comprehensive analysis of the temperature response of soil respiration to warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for further research to improve our mechanistic understanding of the response of soil respiration to climate change. This is critical to improving our ability to predict the fate of soil carbon in a warmer world.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because of the difficulty in observing the transition in a single organism. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a common feature of many modern parasitic plants, is linked to a gradual relaxation of purifying selection on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the result of a combination of natural variability and anthropogenic climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the drought by a factor of five to six. This result highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk will increase substantially in the future, and that the current drought is likely to become more common. This will have significant implications for water supply, food security, and economic development in SSA.

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first nuclear test explosion, is of great significance for the history of science, the history of technology, and the history of the Cold War.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The capture of solar radiation is mediated by the pigments chlorophyll and bacteriochlorophyll, which are synthesized by a common biosynthetic pathway. The formation of the fifth ring of these pigments, the isocyclic ring, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll. (Photosynthesis is the process by which plants, algae, and other photosynthetic organisms convert solar radiation into chemical energy.) (Less)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and astrocytes produced key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the glial cells and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.
