We find that the probability of drought has increased in California over the past few decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a framework for the analysis of the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes in the etiology of autism. This framework can be extended to other complex disorders with a complicated etiology.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in ORAI1, which are associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

We have developed a model system to study the spreading of protein aggregates in the brain. This model can be used to study the mechanisms of spreading, the role of endocytosis in the spreading of aggregates, and the potential for therapeutic intervention.

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may provide a new perspective for the development of antiviral strategies for the prevention and treatment of viral diseases in humans and animals. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which is highly effective in cancer cells. We have also identified a unique metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously difficult to treat. Our work provides a new target for the treatment of cancer, and a new therapeutic strategy for the treatment of lymphoma.

We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other tissues. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, and not merely a consequence of the presence of the same proteins in the same tissues in the general population.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be used to study many-body physics of quantum matter, including the effects of the photonic crystal on the properties of the atoms, and the effects of the atoms on the photonic crystal.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils from the Cretaceous period. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a flowering plant from the Cretaceous period. The study of Montsechia provides new insights into the origin of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the fields of virology and evolutionary biology. However, the study of virus evolution has been hindered by the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of human parvovirus B19. We find that the evolution of B19V is much slower than previously thought, and we are able to date the origin of B19V to ∼12.6 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

We provide a new estimate of the rate of sea level change over the last 25 y, which is the longest period for which we have a consistent time series of satellite altimeter data. This rate is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which is about twice the rate of acceleration observed in the 20th century. This acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration observed in the 20th century, and it is consistent with the rate of acceleration implied by the IPCC AR5 models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern of increasing pain with age is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of a transition state with the first product of an enzyme reaction. This work provides a detailed picture of the reaction of the first product of the reaction, which is a defining species for many enzymes.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus, which has a high case fatality rate. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the only treatment options available are supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in humans, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection in humans, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit to the global community in the fight against the current pandemic.

This paper is about the symbiosis between a squid and its luminescent bacteria. The bacteria are very important for the squid, because they produce light, which is used for communication and for finding mates. The squid provides the bacteria with a special nutrient, which the bacteria use to produce light. The paper is about the timing of the delivery of this nutrient.
This paper is about the importance of relationships in schools, and the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. It is also about the power of small interventions to change the world.

This study provides important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from this study are expected to provide a better understanding of the role of alkylation in transcriptional mutagenesis and the development of novel therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes pneumonia in humans. The virus infects human lung cells, but the mechanisms that allow it to enter these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that the sequential proteolysis of the spike protein is required for infection of human lung cells, and that the first cleavages are important determinants of the host range of the virus.

This paper provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This has important implications for the food system, as it suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the health of the population and the environment. The paper also provides evidence that this approach is effective in the real world, and that it can be implemented without a significant impact on overall sales. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets in a variety of settings, including universities, hospitals, and workplaces.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we provide a systems-level view of how the surfaceome is remodeled in cancer cells, and how this isoform remodeling is driven by specific oncogenes. We also provide a method for the analysis of the glycome, which is the surface of the cell, and show that oncogenes have a dramatic impact on the glycome. These studies provide a foundation for the discovery of surface targets and combinations thereof for drug and biomarker discovery.

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique structure and function not previously described for this protein.

Cerebral edema is a common and potentially life-threatening condition, but the mechanisms underlying its development are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the increase in AQP4 expression is mediated by the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) pathway. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We live in an era of big data, where the size of the data sets is so large that it is difficult to examine all of the data. In this paper, we describe a new way of dealing with this problem, which is to “cherry pick” the data that we examine. We illustrate the use of this approach in three common statistical methods: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We show that this approach can lead to more powerful statistical tests.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult, and the development of a method to generate vascular networks is needed. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can induce the development of vascular networks from human fibroblasts. This study provides a method for the generation of vascular networks, which can be used for the regeneration of organs.

We report the discovery of a new class of ligands for the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We also report the discovery of a new role for these ligands in the development of the zebrafish eye and iridophore.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex metabolic disorder, and the molecular basis of T2D is still unclear. In this study, we found that STING plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a decrease in β-cell function-related gene expression, which led to impaired GSIS. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which is a unique feature of the virus. The packaging of the viral genome is a critical step in the assembly of the virus, and the mechanism of this process is not well understood. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. We show that this interaction is required for the packaging of the viral genome and is essential for optimal viral replication. Our results provide insights into the packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. They also suggest that the interaction we identified might be a target for antiviral drug development. (Show more)

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The results have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that the majority of these fires were started intentionally. We recommend that efforts to reduce wildfire risk should focus on reducing the number of ignitions, and that public education and outreach should be a key component of any such efforts.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to show that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control, but their direct molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the time between infection and the onset of viral production is short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is long. We also show that an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the treatment is most effective when given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. Finally, we show that a drug that inhibits viral replication is more effective than one that inhibits viral production. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is accompanied by a loss of the reef-building capacity of the host. However, the underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a dynamic organ that is able to respond to the presence of tumors and the dysbiotic microbiome. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which is important for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for the development of therapeutic strategies to control tumorigenesis.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is an important determinant of the outcome of the disease. In this study, we found that chemotherapy treatment of breast cancer cells enhanced the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1, which in turn enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to form tumors in mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer.

The start of deglaciation is one of the most important events in the Earth’s history, but the cause is still debated. We show that a volcanic eruption series, which is known to have occurred at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a climate change that was similar to that observed today.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in global assessments of the state of the world’s fisheries. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect biodiversity in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. We report the discovery of a form of regeneration in the nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for the study of regeneration in general, as well as for the treatment of injury in the nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of the species. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that the distribution of recombination rates is similar to that in yeast and in mice.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized in functionally distinct networks, which are active in different states of consciousness. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been controversial. Here, we used metabolic PET to validate the existence of RSNs in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct link between resting brain networks and their functional role in health and disease.

This paper is about the structure of the 5′ end of messenger RNA. It is a very important structure because it is the first thing that the ribosome sees when it starts translating the RNA. The authors describe a new structure, which they call a cap, at the 5′ end of messenger RNA. This is the first description of a cap in eukaryotes.

We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood are associated with glycemia for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and that these alterations are similar in blood monocytes and in blood cells of the same person. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.
This study provides a comprehensive understanding of the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms underlying the development of the disease are not fully understood, but it is clear that the brain is involved in the development of the disorder. In this study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study may also provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, and the production of many of these compounds is not well understood. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of a large number of these compounds, and we demonstrate that this gene is a member of a family of enzymes that catalyze sequential hydroxylation reactions. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and it opens the door to the development of improved varieties with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This finding has important implications for the future functioning of ecosystems, as it suggests that the loss of biodiversity through global warming will result in a loss of ecosystem function. Our results also highlight the importance of considering the effects of temperature change on the thermal tolerance curves of species, as this is a key determinant of the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is of great interest. Here, we report the results of a large-scale, free-moving, in-depth analysis of the anatomical and functional properties of neurons in MEC. We show that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for the formation of a spatial map of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they exhibit a unique functional organization. These results provide a foundation for future studies of the functional organization of MEC.

Dodder is a rootless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the flowering signal in dodder is not produced by the FT gene, but by the interaction of FT and a dodder FD transcription factor. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model for understanding the evolution of flowering regulation in plants. View Full-Text

This paper is about the brain, but it is also about the power of the microscope. It is about the power of the microscope to reveal the structure of the brain, and the power of the microscope to reveal the structure of the brain in a way that is not possible with the naked eye.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.” This signal is used by people to assess the quality of their connections with others, and it is used by others to assess the quality of connections between people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart, and its function is critical for the normal heart rate and blood pressure. However, the mechanisms that regulate SAN function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN function. We found that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and its deletion in mice resulted in a reduction in the size of the Ca2+ stores of the SAN, leading to a reduction in heart rate. These results suggest that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN that links the size of the Ca2+ stores with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased resistance against the insect herbivore Cnaphalocrocis medinalis in rice plants, and that this effect was associated with enhanced levels of jasmonic acid (JA) and Si accumulation. Our results suggest that Si may promote insect herbivore resistance by priming JA-mediated defense responses. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores. (Show more)

This paper is about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. It is about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of ether lipids, which are important for the immune system, and about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of other lipids, which are important for the immune system.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rate of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to the context of the stimulus and can be used to bind information over time.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, and geometry of the DNA nanostructures are important for the delivery of the biomolecules to the plant cells. We also show that the location of the attachment of the siRNA to the DNA nanostructures is important for the delivery of the biomolecules to the plant cells. This work establishes the feasibility of the delivery of biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. This work also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant biotechnology. We show that the majority of the nutrients that enter Lake Michigan come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings have important implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as well as for the understanding of the role of small tributaries in the global nitrogen cycle.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the network’s possible states. We find that the network’s dynamics are biased toward states that are extremized with respect to the environment’s forcing.

The history of carbon perturbation events throughout Earth’s history is critical for understanding the Earth system response to abrupt warming. Here, we present a new case study of an event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. Our results provide insights into the Earth system response to abrupt warming and the role of organic matter in the biogeochemical cycle of carbon.

Certification of palm oil production is a major effort to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been evaluated in a systematic way. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is one of the most fundamental aspects of animal biology. In this study, we investigate the effects of sex determination on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in a species with multiple sex determination alleles. We find that the interplay of multiple sex determination alleles in a species can result in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be used to track the evolution of the sex determination system.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by the presence of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A. In this study, we show that the presence of iron in the retina promotes the oxidation and degradation of a class of photoproducts of vitamin A. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve new morphological features that are optimized for a specific prey type. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophore tentilla is linked to prey type, and that these changes are associated with shifts in the evolution of the whole organism. These findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the role of morphological evolution in the development of biodiversity.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in the field of human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This finding also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the hand in the hominin lineage leading to the evolution of modern humans. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon unit provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which is highly effective in vitro and in vivo. We have also identified a unique dependence of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma on SHMT enzymatic activity, which is rooted in defective glycine import. These findings provide a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

We show that deforestation has a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by forest fragmentation. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the modern agricultural revolution, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods, the largest terrestrial animals that ever lived, would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the importance of the mechanical properties of the soil in the design of farm machinery and the need for a more stringent design of vehicles to reduce subsoil compaction. It also suggests that the roaming of sauropods may have had a significant impact on the productivity of the land. View Full-Text
